rev.comment: no rationale for use, image available and discussed at main article, per [[Wikipedia:NFC#Images_2]]

Line 36: Line 36:
==Photography==
==Photography==
[[Image:Taj Mahal 1921.JPG|left|300px|thumb|Color photograph of the [[Taj Mahal]]. Source: ''The National Geographic Magazine'', March 1921]]
[[Image:Taj Mahal 1921.JPG|left|300px|thumb|Color photograph of the [[Taj Mahal]]. Source: ''The National Geographic Magazine'', March 1921]]
â
[[File:Sharbat Gula.png|right|200px|thumb|The iconic [[Afghan Girl (photo)|Afghan Girl photo]]. Source: ''National Geographic'', June 1985]]
 
In addition to being well-known for articles about scenery, history, and the most distant corners of the world, the magazine has been recognized for its book-like quality and its standard of [[photography]]. This standard makes it the home to some of the highest-quality [[photojournalism]] in the world. The magazine began to feature [[color photography]] in the early 20th century, when this technology was still rare. During the 1930s, [[Luis Marden]] (1913-2003), a writer and photographer for ''National Geographic'', convinced the magazine to allow its photographers to use small 35 mm cameras loaded with [[Kodachrome]] film over bulkier cameras with [[Tripod (photography)|tripod]]s and [[photographic plate|glass plates]]. In 1959, the magazine started publishing small photographs on its covers, later becoming larger photographs. National Geographic photography has quickly shifted to digital photography for both its magazine on paper and its website. In subsequent years, the magazine cover, while keeping its yellow border, shed its oak leaf trim and bare table of contents, for a large photograph taken from one of the month's articles inside. National Geographic are often kept by subscribers for years and re-sold at thrift stores as collectible back-issues. In 2006, National Geographic began an international photography competition with over eighteen countries participating.
In addition to being well-known for articles about scenery, history, and the most distant corners of the world, the magazine has been recognized for its book-like quality and its standard of [[photography]]. This standard makes it the home to some of the highest-quality [[photojournalism]] in the world. The magazine began to feature [[color photography]] in the early 20th century, when this technology was still rare. During the 1930s, [[Luis Marden]] (1913-2003), a writer and photographer for ''National Geographic'', convinced the magazine to allow its photographers to use small 35 mm cameras loaded with [[Kodachrome]] film over bulkier cameras with [[Tripod (photography)|tripod]]s and [[photographic plate|glass plates]]. In 1959, the magazine started publishing small photographs on its covers, later becoming larger photographs. National Geographic photography has quickly shifted to digital photography for both its magazine on paper and its website. In subsequent years, the magazine cover, while keeping its yellow border, shed its oak leaf trim and bare table of contents, for a large photograph taken from one of the month's articles inside. National Geographic are often kept by subscribers for years and re-sold at thrift stores as collectible back-issues. In 2006, National Geographic began an international photography competition with over eighteen countries participating.
